Action: Prioritize drug class from abstract title over all other sources
Example_Input: Drug: Drug A | Abstract title: Drug A, a CAR-T cell therapy | Extracted Content: Drug A is a PD-1 inhibitor
Generated_Rule: If the abstract title mentions a drug class for the given drug, that class must be prioritized over all others, including MoA. Capture only the drug class mentioned in the abstract title, ignore all classes (MoA, therapeutic, chemical, mode) from other sources, and do not derive or infer anything further.

Action: MoA has highest priority - capture only MoA when present; if multiple MoAs choose most specific or one appearing across multiple sources
Example_Input: Drug A is a selective PDL1 inhibitor. Drug A is also an antidepressant. | Drug B is a BRAF V600E inhibitor and also a kinase inhibitor.
Generated_Rule: If the extracted content or full abstract text mentions a Mechanism of Action (MoA), capture only the MoA and ignore all other classes (chemical, mode, therapeutic), even if they are also present. MoA examples include: PDL1-Inhibitor, FLAP Inhibitor, GLP-1 Agonist. If multiple MoAs appear, choose the most specific MoA OR the one appearing across multiple sources when several are equally specific.

Action: Capture all available lower priority classes when MoA is absent
Example_Input: Drug C belongs to the thiazide chemical family. | Drug D acts as a bronchodilator. | Drug E is classified as an antidepressant. | Drug F is a thiazide diuretic with bronchodilator properties.
Generated_Rule: If MoA is not mentioned in any source, capture all available classes among Chemical Class (e.g., Thiazide, Benzodiazepine), Mode of Action (e.g., Bronchodilator, Vasoconstrictor), and Therapeutic Class (e.g., Antidepressant, Anticancer) as separate elements in the drug_classes array, since they share equal priority.

Action: Maintain Title Case for drug class names; use uppercase for gene/cell names when content uses all caps
Example_Input: flt3 inhibitor
Generated_Rule: Maintain Title Case for drug class names. Use uppercase for gene/cell names only when the content uses them in all caps. Examples: 'FLT3 Inhibitor', 'CD19 CAR-T Cell Therapy'. Maintain consistent capitalization and spelling. Gene symbols and biomarkers should follow standard nomenclature.

Action: Remove leading and trailing spaces
Example_Input: PDL1-Inhibitor
Generated_Rule: Ensure there is no leading or trailing space around the drug class tokens. Trim all whitespace from the beginning and end of each drug class string.

Action: Capture drug class names only in singular form
Example_Input: PD-1 Inhibitors
Generated_Rule: Capture drug class names only in singular form (e.g., 'Antibody' not 'Antibodies', 'Inhibitor' not 'Inhibitors').

Action: Return multiple classes as separate strings in the array
Example_Input: Drug has two mechanisms: PD-1 inhibitor and CTLA-4 inhibitor.
Generated_Rule: Return multiple drug classes as separate strings in the drug_classes array. Each class should be a distinct element.

Action: Capture drug class exactly as written without generalizing subtypes
Example_Input: Drug A is a cytolytic antibody. | Drug B is a monoclonal antibody.
Generated_Rule: Do not generalize or alter subtype wording. Capture the drug class, MoA, or subtype exactly as written in the provided content (after applying required formatting rules like Title Case and hyphenation). Examples: If source says 'cytolytic antibody', capture 'Cytolytic Antibody' — do not change to 'Antibody'. If source says 'monoclonal antibody', capture 'Monoclonal Antibody' — do not change to 'Antibody'.

Action: Hyphenate target and modality; maintain original hyphenated root names
Example_Input: BM1 targeted therapy | BCR-ABL inhibitor
Generated_Rule: When formatting drug classes with targets, hyphenate the target and modality (e.g., 'BM1-Targeted Therapy' not 'BM1 Targeted Therapy'). Maintain original hyphenated root names when present in the source content (e.g., 'BCR-ABL Inhibitor' not 'BCRABL Inhibitor').

Action: Convert Anti-X to X-Targeted Therapy or X-Targeted Antibody depending on modality
Example_Input: Drug is an anti-PD1 antibody.
Generated_Rule: If the content uses 'Anti-X' or 'anti-X' format, convert to 'X-Targeted Therapy' or 'X-Targeted Antibody' depending on the modality mentioned in the text.

Action: List multiple targets alphabetically
Example_Input: Drug targets CD20 and CD3.
Generated_Rule: If multiple targets are mentioned, list them alphabetically (e.g., 'CD3/CD20-Targeted T Cell Engager' not 'CD20/CD3-...').

Action: Include biological target when known using TARGET-Modality format
Example_Input: Drug Y inhibits PDL1.
Generated_Rule: Always include biological target when known, using the format TARGET-Modality or TARGET-Inhibitor (e.g., 'PDL1-Inhibitor', 'CTLA4-Targeted Antibody', 'CD19-Targeted CAR T Therapy').

Action: Include platform + target for platform therapies like PROTAC and BITE
Example_Input: Drug Z is an AR-targeted PROTAC. | Drug AA is a CD3/CD20 bispecific T cell engager.
Example_Output: AR-Targeted PROTAC | CD3/CD20-Targeted Bispecific T-Cell Engager
Generated_Rule: For platform therapies like PROTAC or BITE (Bispecific T cell Engager), include platform + target (e.g., 'AR-Targeted PROTAC', 'CD3/CD20-Targeted Bispecific T-Cell Engager').

Action: Add Inhibitor when blockade/blocker/inhibitor terms occur; convert Blockade to Inhibitor; include virus/organism name when mentioned
Example_Input: Drug A is a PD-1 blocker. | Drug B works through PD-1 blockade. | Drug C is a BK virus inhibitor.
Example_Output: PD-1 Inhibitor | PD-1 Inhibitor | BK Virus Inhibitor
Generated_Rule: If the content mentions blockade, blocker, or inhibitor terms, always add Inhibitor as a drug class. Format as TARGET-Inhibitor where applicable. Convert 'Blockade' terminology (e.g., 'PD-1 Blockade') to Inhibitor format (e.g., 'PD-1 Inhibitor'). If a virus or organism is mentioned with an inhibitor, include the virus/organism name in the drug class (e.g., 'BK Virus Inhibitor').

Action: Capture stimulants with organ/system when mentioned
Example_Input: Drug D is a CNS stimulant.
Generated_Rule: If the content mentions a stimulant, capture it with the organ or system when mentioned (e.g., 'CNS Stimulant', 'Cardiac Stimulant').

Action: Capture Agonist or Antagonist when explicitly stated with target
Example_Input: Drug E is a GLP-1 agonist. | Drug F is an EGFR antagonist.
Generated_Rule: If the content explicitly states 'Agonist' or 'Antagonist', capture it as a drug class with its target (e.g., 'GLP-1 Agonist', 'Dopamine Agonist', 'EGFR Antagonist', 'H2 Antagonist').

Action: Capture when explicitly mentioned with targets if specified
Example_Input: Drug G is a bispecific antibody targeting CD3 and CD20. | Drug H is a trispecific antibody.
Generated_Rule: If the content explicitly mentions 'Bispecific Antibody' or 'Trispecific Antibody', capture it as a drug class. Include targets if specified.

Action: Add ICI when immune checkpoint modality indicated - prefer specific target over general ICI
Example_Input: Drug I is an immune checkpoint inhibitor.
Generated_Rule: If the content indicates an immune checkpoint modality, add 'Immune Checkpoint Inhibitor' as a drug class. However, prefer specific target hyphenation if available (e.g., 'PD-1 Inhibitor' over the general 'Immune Checkpoint Inhibitor').

Action: Capture Modulator or Degrader when it appears with target
Example_Input: Drug J is an estrogen receptor modulator. | Drug K is a PROTAC degrader targeting AR.
Generated_Rule: If the content mentions 'Modulator' or 'Degrader', capture it as a drug class with its target when specified.

Action: Capture Gene Therapy when mentioned; capture Hormonal Therapy for hormone-targeting contexts; map ADT to Hormonal Therapy
Example_Input: Drug L is a gene therapy for hemophilia. | Drug M is used for androgen deprivation therapy. | Patient received ADT treatment.
Example_Output: Gene Therapy | Hormonal Therapy | Hormonal Therapy
Generated_Rule: If the content mentions 'Gene Therapy', capture it as a drug class. If the content mentions 'Hormonal Therapy', 'Androgen Deprivation', or 'ADT' (Androgen Deprivation Therapy), capture as 'Hormonal Therapy'. Do not list anything additional for ADT.

Action: Capture engager platforms (BIKE/TRIKE/SMITE) when mentioned
Example_Input: Drug N is a BIKE targeting CD3/CD19. | Drug O is a TRIKE therapeutic. | Drug P is a SMITE molecule.
Generated_Rule: If the content mentions engager platforms such as 'BIKE' (Bispecific Killer cell Engager), 'TRIKE' (Trispecific Killer cell Engager), or 'SMITE' (Small Molecule Immune T cell Engager), capture each as a drug class. Include targets if specified.

Action: Capture Agent classes in singular form
Example_Input: Drug Q is a hypomethylating agent.
Generated_Rule: If the content mentions a drug class with 'Agent' (e.g., 'Hypomethylating Agent', 'Alkylating Agent'), capture it as-is in singular form.

Action: Classify PET imaging agents and radio tracers as Diagnostic Imaging Agent
Example_Input: Drug is 18F-FDG used for PET imaging. | Drug is 68Ga-PSMA for prostate cancer detection. | Drug is a radiotracer for cardiac imaging.
Example_Output: Diagnostic Imaging Agent | Diagnostic Imaging Agent | Diagnostic Imaging Agent
Generated_Rule: Drug class for all PET imaging agents, diagnostic agents, radio tracers, and similar compounds (such as 18F-FDG, 68Ga-PSMA, technetium-based agents) should be 'Diagnostic Imaging Agent'.

Action: Classify mineral-based drug compounds as Mineral Supplement
Example_Input: Drug is magnesium sulfate for seizure prevention. | Drug is potassium chloride for hypokalemia. | Drug is calcium gluconate.
Example_Output: Mineral Supplement | Mineral Supplement | Mineral Supplement
Generated_Rule: Drug class for all mineral-based compounds used as drugs (such as Magnesium, Calcium, Potassium, Zinc, Iron supplements) should be 'Mineral Supplement'.

Action: Classify all vaccine types as Vaccine
Example_Input: Drug is an mRNA vaccine. | Drug is a live attenuated vaccine. | Drug is a cancer vaccine.
Generated_Rule: Drug class for all different types of vaccines (mRNA vaccines, live attenuated vaccines, inactivated vaccines, subunit vaccines, cancer vaccines, etc.) should be 'Vaccine'.

Action: Convert cell types to therapy format by appending 'therapy'; retain exact cell type; do not infer from other sources
Example_Input: Drug R is a stem cell product. | Drug S uses autologous hematopoietic cells. | Drug T is an autologous hematopoietic stem cell therapy. | Drug U is a CAR-T cell product. | Drug V is an NK cell therapy. | Drug W uses dendritic cells.
Example_Output: Stem Cell Therapy | Autologous Hematopoietic Cell Therapy | Autologous Hematopoietic Stem Cell Therapy | CAR-T Cell Therapy | NK Cell Therapy | Dendritic Cell Therapy
Generated_Rule: When a cell type is mentioned for the drug, convert it to therapy format by appending 'therapy'. This rule should be followed for all similar cases. Examples: Stem cell → Stem Cell Therapy; Autologous hematopoietic cell → Autologous Hematopoietic Cell Therapy; Autologous hematopoietic stem cell → Autologous Hematopoietic Stem Cell Therapy; CAR-T cell → CAR-T Cell Therapy; NK cell → NK Cell Therapy; Dendritic cell → Dendritic Cell Therapy. Retain the exact cell type as it appears (no paraphrasing), only append 'therapy'. Do NOT change capitalization beyond normal title case. Do NOT refer to other sources to infer or expand cell therapy modality/class.

Action: Do not capture abbreviations unless spelled out
Example_Input: Drug is an ADC. | Drug is an ICI. | Drug is a TKI. | Drug is a BITE.
Generated_Rule: Do NOT capture abbreviated drug classes (ADC, ICI, TKI, BITE, etc.) unless they are spelled out. ADC must be spelled out as 'Antibody Drug Conjugate'. ICI must be spelled out as 'Immune Checkpoint Inhibitor'. TKI must be spelled out as 'Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitor'. BITE must be spelled out or accompanied by specific targets. Abbreviations alone are not acceptable.

Action: Do not extract when drug class is in conference title, previously treated context, induced disease/adverse event, or treatment failure
Example_Input: Antimicrobial Stewardship Program conference | NSCLC patients previously treated with EGFR-Inhibitor | EGFR-Inhibitor Related Cardiac Dysfunction | Patient failed prior TKI therapy
Generated_Rule: Do NOT extract drug class names in the following contexts: (1) Part of a conference or program title (e.g., 'Antimicrobial Stewardship Program' → do not extract 'Antimicrobial'); (2) Prior/previous treatment context (e.g., 'previously treated with EGFR-Inhibitor'); (3) Mentioned as a cause or induced adverse event (e.g., 'EGFR-Inhibitor Related Cardiac Dysfunction'); (4) Treatment failure or resistance context (e.g., 'failed prior TKI therapy').

Action: Do not add generic therapy headings as drug classes without specific target or modality
Example_Input: Patient received chemotherapy. | Patient received immunotherapy. | Drug is a targeted therapy. | Drug is an antibody. | Drug has anti-tumor activity. | Drug is a small molecule. | Drug is an antineoplastic agent.
Generated_Rule: Do NOT add broad therapy headings as drug classes unless the content gives a specific target or modality. Exclude these generic labels: Chemotherapy, Immunotherapy, Radiation Therapy (except if conference specifically focuses on it and context implies MoA), Immunosuppressant, Anti-tumor, Anti-cancer, Antibody (alone - must be accompanied by specific target or type), Targeted Therapy (alone - only include when target is specified), Small Molecule (alone), Hormone (alone - use 'Hormonal Therapy' when hormone-targeting context is present), Immunotherapeutic, Hormone Stimulation Therapy, Antineoplastic Agent.

Action: Do not capture diseases, procedures, interventions, clinical endpoints, or unrelated biomedical terms
Example_Input: Drug treats breast cancer. | Drug used in surgery. | Drug affects cell proliferation.
Generated_Rule: Do NOT capture diseases, conditions, diagnoses, procedures, interventions, clinical endpoints, biological processes, or unrelated biomedical terms as drug classes.

Action: Return NA when no class found and do not invent or infer
Example_Input: No mechanism information provided.
Generated_Rule: If the extracted content does not provide a drug class or required field, return 'NA'. Do NOT invent or infer a drug class.

Action: Do not add Adjuvant as Mechanism of Action
Example_Input: Drug is used as adjuvant therapy.
Generated_Rule: Do NOT add 'Adjuvant' as a Mechanism of Action. It describes treatment timing, not mechanism.

Action: Always capture these drug classes when present: TIL Therapy; Antibody Drug Conjugate (spelled out); Exon Skipping Therapy
Example_Input: Drug is a TIL therapy. | Drug is an antibody drug conjugate. | Drug is an exon skipping therapy.
Example_Output: TIL Therapy | Antibody Drug Conjugate | Exon Skipping Therapy
Generated_Rule: Always capture the following drug classes when present in the content, as exceptions to general rules: 'TIL Therapy' (Tumor Infiltrating Lymphocyte Therapy), 'Antibody Drug Conjugate' (when spelled out), 'Exon Skipping Therapy'.

Action: Map Platelet-rich Plasma to Plasma Therapy
Example_Input: Drug uses platelet-rich plasma.
Generated_Rule: If the content mentions 'Platelet-rich Plasma', map it to the drug class 'Plasma Therapy'.

Action: Avoid Anti-Metabolite when more specific MoA available
Example_Input: Drug is an anti-metabolite and DHFR inhibitor.
Generated_Rule: Avoid adding 'Anti-Metabolite' when a more specific MoA is available in the content.

Action: Avoid incorrect spellings in MoAs and use standard nomenclature
Example_Input: Drug is a PD-L1 inhibitor (not PDL-1)
Generated_Rule: Watch for and avoid incorrect spellings in extracted MoAs. Use standard nomenclature for gene symbols and drug class terms.

Action: Capture MoAs only for primary drugs not secondary/comparator drugs
Example_Input: Primary: Drug A (PD-1 inhibitor) vs Comparator: Drug B (chemotherapy)
Generated_Rule: MoAs should be captured only for primary drugs, not secondary or comparator drugs mentioned in the content.

Action: Segregate regimens into compound drugs and extract drug class for each component
Example_Input: FOLFOX regimen contains 5-FU and oxaliplatin. | R-CHOP regimen includes rituximab and cyclophosphamide.
Generated_Rule: Regimens must be segregated into compound drugs, and drug classes must be extracted for each compound drug. If the primary drug is a regimen and component drugs are explicitly listed in the content, include the drug class for each component as separate elements in the list.
